content.text: Define _resistance
A potential difference of \(0.60 \text{V}\) is applied across a resistor of resistance \(4.0 \text{G} \Omega\)
Calculate the current, in pA, in the resistor
current =   .........  pA
The energy \(E\) transferred when charge \(Q\) moves through an electrical component is given by the equation
where \(V\) is the potential difference across the component
Use the equation to determine the SI base units of potential difference
SI base units   .........
State an expression for:
1. the work \(W\) done by the force, in terms of \(a\), \(m\) and \(s\)
2. the distance \(s\), in terms of \(a\), \(u\) and \(v\)
Use your answers in **(i)** to show that the kinetic energy of the object is given by
Explain your working

A resultant force \(F\) moves an object of mass \(m\) through distance \(s\) in a straight line. The force gives the object an acceleration \(a\) so that its speed changes from initial speed \(u\) to final speed \(v\)
For the movement of the ball from X to Y, draw a solid line on Fig. 2.1 to show:
1. the distance moved (label this line D)
2. the displacement (label this line S)
By consideration of energy transfer, determine the height \(h\) of point Y above the ground
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation of the kinetic energy of the ball with its vertical height above the ground for the movement of the ball from X to Y
Numerical values are not required
A ball of mass \(0.040\mathrm{kg}\) is projected into the air from horizontal ground, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1
The ball is launched from a point X with a kinetic energy of 4.5 J. At point Y, the ball has a speed of \(9.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\). Air resistance is negligible
Determine the rate of doing work on the disc by the force X
rate of doing work =   .........  W
The force X and the weight of the disc exert a combined pressure on the ground of \(3500 \text{Pa}\)
Calculate the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the disc
the direction of force Y
the name of the body on which force Y acts
Newton's third law describes how forces exist in pairs. One such pair of forces is the weight of the disc and another force Y. State:
A cylindrical disc of mass \(0.24\mathrm{kg}\) has a circular cross-sectional area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 3.1

The disc is on horizontal ground, as shown in Fig. 3.2. A force X of magnitude \(8.9 \text{N}\) acts on the disc in a direction of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The disc moves at a constant speed of \(0.60 \text{m s}^{-1}\) along the ground
Describe the pattern of the field lines (lines of force) between the plates
State the names of the two forces acting on the particle as it moves from X to Y
By considering the vertical motion of the sand particle, show that the time taken for the particle to move from X to Y is 0.64 s
Calculate the horizontal component of the acceleration of the particle
horizontal component of acceleration = ............................................ \(\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)
Calculate the magnitude of the electric field strength
electric field strength =   .........  \(\text{NC}^{-1}\)
The sand particle has mass \(m\) and charge \(q\). Use your answers in **(d)** and **(e)**(i) to determine the ratio \(\frac{q}{m}\)
the vertical component of the acceleration
the horizontal component of the acceleration
Another particle has a smaller magnitude of the ratio \(\frac{q}{m}\) than the sand particle. This particle is also released from point X
For the movement of this particle, state the effect, if any, of the decreased magnitude of the ratio on:
Two vertical metal plates in a vacuum are separated by a distance of \(0.12 \text{m}\)
Fig. 4.1 shows a side view of this arrangement
(not to scale)
Each plate has a length of \(2.0 \text{m}\). The potential difference between the plates is \(900 \text{V}\). The electric field between the plates is uniform

A negatively charged sand particle is released from rest at point X, which is a horizontal distance of \(0.080 \text{m}\) from the top of the positively charged plate. The particle then travels in a straight line and collides with the positively charged plate at its lowest point Y, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1
Explain how the stationary wave is formed from the incident sound wave
On Fig. 5.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the amplitude of the stationary wave with height \(h\) above the bottom of the tube
the direction of the oscillations of an air particle at a height of \(0.15 \text{m}\) above the bottom of the tube
the phase difference between the oscillations of a particle at a height of \(0.10 \text{m}\) and a particle at a height of \(0.20 \text{m}\) above the bottom of the tube
phase difference =   .........
For the stationary wave, state:
The speed of the sound wave is \(340 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 1}\)
Calculate the frequency of the sound wave
frequency =   .........  Hz
The frequency of the sound wave is gradually increased
Determine the frequency of the wave when a stationary wave is next formed
frequency =   .........  Hz
A vertical tube of length \(0.60 \text{m}\) is open at both ends, as shown in Fig. 5.1
An incident sinusoidal sound wave of a single frequency travels up the tube. A stationary wave is then formed in the air column in the tube with antinodes A at both ends and a node N at the midpoint
Define the \(ohm\)

resistance \(R_{\mathrm{Z}}\)

content.text: Resistors X and Y are each made of wire. The two wires have the same length and are made of the same metal
Determine the ratio:
cross-sectional area of wire X
cross-sectional area of wire Y
average drift speed of free electrons in X
average drift speed of free electrons in Y'
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(1.5\Omega\) is connected to a network of resistors, as shown in Fig. 6.1

Resistor X has a resistance of \(8.0\Omega\). Resistor Y has a resistance of \(2.0\Omega\). Resistor Z has a resistance of \(R_{\mathrm{Z}}\). The current in X is \(0.60\mathrm{A}\) and the current in Y is \(1.8\mathrm{A}\)
consists of leptons
contains quarks
cannot be deflected by an electric field
has a continuous range of energies, rather than discrete values of energy
A sample of a radioactive substance may decay by the emission of either \(\alpha\) -radiation or \(\beta\) -radiation and/or \(\gamma\) -radiation
State the type of radiation, one in each case, that:
